### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Bentley Tolk (BT): I was attracted to law school because it seemed more academic than business school, and because I believed it would allow me to use research, writing and speaking skills. My wife and I applied to law school as a “package deal,” and the University of Chicago Law School was one of the fine law schools that accepted both of us. We were the only “married couple” in the first-year class.

RC: After 22 years of the legal practice, what motivated you to begin podcasting?

BT: I believe that audio podcasting is one of the best business development platforms for lawyers, because many potential clients don’t have time to sit at a computer to read or watch a lawyer’s content. Audio podcasting literally allows busy lawyers, clients and potential clients to listen to a lawyer’s content while multi-tasking.

Thus, if a lawyer would like to reach other lawyers or busy potential clients, the advantage of podcasting is that other lawyers or potential clients can listen and learn while commuting, exercising, getting ready for work, walking the dog, preparing for bed, or even brushing their teeth! As a business development tool, podcasting can be unmatched in that potential clients can hear a lawyer’s voice on a consistent basis, helping potential clients come to know, like and trust the lawyer. Articles, videos and speeches don’t allow lawyers the same convenience and consistency of contact with potential clients.

RC: For those who plan to produce their own podcast one day, what advice do you have for them?

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
BT: First, choose several podcast topics that interest you. Second, use Google or some other source to research several topics that would be of interest to your target audience. Third, choose a topic that overlaps between your interests and those of your target audience. Fourth, invest in a paid course or courses from someone who is already podcasting.

Finally, once you have chosen your topic and have received some training, start the process of podcasting before you believe you are ready and before your product is “perfect.” Per the quote attributed to Reid Hoffman, the founder of LinkedIn, “If you are not embarrassed by the first version of your product, you’ve launched too late.”

RC: Who have been some of your most interesting or notable interviewees and why?

BT: Paul Anderson ([episode 69](http://www.legalmarketinglaunch.com/069-lessons-from-marketing-a-concussion-litigation-practice-paul-anderson/)) and Lindsey Zahn ([episode 132](http://www.legalmarketinglaunch.com/132-lessons-from-marketing-a-wine-and-beverage-law-practice-lindsey-zahn/)) are good examples of lawyers who chose a narrow niche and became thought leaders in that niche through blogging early on in their legal careers: concussion litigation for Paul, and wine law for Lindsey. John Scannapieco ([episode 49](http://www.legalmarketinglaunch.com/049-global-legal-marketing-john-scannapieco/)) explains how a lawyer can think big and create a thriving international practice, starting from square one.

Finally, Jordan Furlong ([Episode 63](http://www.legalmarketinglaunch.com/063-the-effect-of-current-and-future-trends-on-legal-marketing-jordan-furlong/)) provides timely advice on how current and future trends in the legal profession should affect one’s business development strategies.

RC: Season I was absolutely fantastic for law firm marketing and client development tips and advice. For Season II, what can listeners expect to hear or learn about when they [subscribe](https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/legal-marketing-launch-bentley/id1006640170) to your podcast?

BT: In my opinion, and due to the high quality of the interviewees, Season I contains one of the most comprehensive libraries in existence of cutting-edge business development ideas and motivation for lawyers.

Season II will include more of the same, along with an additional focus on (1) client development strategies from leaders in bar associations and special-interest groups in the legal profession; and (2) how third-year law students and new lawyers plan to build their legal practices.

Of course, Season II will continue the tradition of asking my interviewees their recommendation on what listeners should do over the next seven days in terms of business development, along with recommendations of a book and an internet resource for the listeners.

RC: What career or business development advice do you have for law school students and young lawyers?

BT: Law school doesn’t teach much about business or practice development. In the next seven days, I recommend that you:

(1) write down where you would like your individual legal practice to be within the next year, five years, and ten years, and post that document somewhere where you will look at it each day;

(2) taking into account what you wrote in step one, write a list of goals – for the next 12 months – for your individual law practice within your law firm;

(3) write down the weekly actions you will take to accomplish each of those goals over the next 12 months; and

(4) set up a system to hold yourself accountable on a weekly basis in working toward those goals. In the meantime, become a student of business development and implement the strategies you are learning, so as to help you reach your goals.

RC: It was great chatting with you. Is there anything else you would like to share with our audience?

BT: As you set business development goals for your practice, emphasize “content marketing.” In other words, find ways to provide high-quality, relevant, free content to your clients and potential clients on a consistent basis, whether through blogging, writing articles, speaking at conferences, etc. Find ways to become known as a “thought leader” in your area of practice.

RC: On behalf of everyone here at Above the Law, I would like to thank Bentley Tolk for sharing his experience and wisdom with our audience. We wish him continued success on the second season of Legal Marketing Launch.

For more business development ideas, please be sure to subscribe to [Legal Marketing Launch](https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/legal-marketing-launch-bentley/id1006640170). If diversity and inclusion in the legal profession is something you are also passionate about, check out [Episode 98 — Diversity In The Legal Profession](http://www.legalmarketinglaunch.com/098-diversity-in-the-legal-profession-renwei-chung/).

[Renwei Chung](http://renweichung.weebly.com/) is the Diversity Columnist at Above the Law. You can contact Renwei by email at [projectrenwei@gmail.com](mailto:projectrenwei@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column), follow him on Twitter ([@renweichung](https://twitter.com/RenweiChung)), or connect with him on [LinkedIn](http://www.linkedin.com/in/renweichung/).

# Biglaw Firms Now Offering Rainmaker Partners Forgivable Loans To Prevent Them From Leaving
## A little extra cash never hurts -- especially if it'll keep top rainmakers from heading to rival law firms.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 20, 2024 at 3:45 PMMarch 20, 2024 at 2:06 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaw-firms-now-offering-rainmaker-partners-forgivable-loans-to-prevent-them-from-leaving/&text=Biglaw%20Firms%20Now%20Offering%20Rainmaker%20Partners%20Forgivable%20Loans%20To%20Prevent%20Them%20From%20Leaving)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaw-firms-now-offering-rainmaker-partners-forgivable-loans-to-prevent-them-from-leaving/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaw-firms-now-offering-rainmaker-partners-forgivable-loans-to-prevent-them-from-leaving/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

You could have someone who wasn’t a partner before and used to getting money on a regular basis … so the firm looks at giving them a forgivable loan. That’s where the firm is trying to address the challenges of a transition.

But there are also forgivable loans when they’re trying to retain somebody and you have to give some back if you don’t stay for a certain amount of time.

— Alisa Levin, principal at Greene-Levin-Snyder Legal Search Group in New York, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2024/03/19/bonuses-with-strings-attached-play-role-in-partner-retention/) on bonuses structured as forgivable loans that have been used as partner retention tools. Firms like Kirkland & Ellis and DLA Piper have reportedly used forgivable loans to keep partners from exiting to rivals, and Shearman & Sterling did the same just prior to its merger with Allen & Overy as a way to “incentivize” partners to stay.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Elite Biglaw Firms Are 'Likely' To Match Milbank, But Will Anyone Raise Salaries Even Higher?
## When will Biglaw firms match the $225K salary scale? All it takes is one firm to start a 'domino' effect.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 9, 2023 at 3:42 PMNovember 9, 2023 at 1:21 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/elite-biglaw-firms-are-likely-to-match-milbank-but-will-anyone-raise-salaries-even-higher/&text=Elite%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Are%20‘Likely’%20To%20Match%20Milbank,%20But%20Will%20Anyone%20Raise%20Salaries%20Even%20Higher?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/elite-biglaw-firms-are-likely-to-match-milbank-but-will-anyone-raise-salaries-even-higher/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/elite-biglaw-firms-are-likely-to-match-milbank-but-will-anyone-raise-salaries-even-higher/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

[I]f every other firm from this moment forward, just held their fire and didn’t raise, it would just be Milbank raising, and no one would need to raise. But history suggests at least one more firm will match, and that’ll cause others, and it’ll domino across the industry.

— [Kent Zimmermann](https://www.consultzg.com/people/kent-zimmermann), a law firm management consultant with the Zeughauser Group, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/11/08/top-performers-likely-to-raise-associate-pay-after-milbank-but-broad-hesitancy-lingers/) on the likelihood that other elite Biglaw firms will match Milbank’s recent [salary raise for associates](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/milbank-raises-associate-salaries-and-announces-year-end-bonuses/). Given the state of the market, Zimmermann said, it “[doesn’t] suggest to most firms that they need to raise compensation in the absence of other firms raising compensation.” Legal analysts believe it is “likely” or “very” likely that at least the top 25 Am Law firms will match the new salary scale, and some firms may even try to go above Milbank’s scale.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# These Biglaw Attorneys Were *Really* Working Overtime On Their Revenue And Value
## What's a lawyer really worth at these firms? Time to find out.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)

# Harvard Law Grad Fired From Biglaw Job After Failing Bar Loses Disability Bias Suit Against Bar Examiners
## It turns out it's not so easy to sue the bar examiners.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 21, 2022 at 12:15 PM
36
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/harvard-law-grad-fired-from-biglaw-job-after-failing-bar-loses-disability-bias-suit-against-bar-examiners/&text=Harvard%20Law%20Grad%20Fired%20From%20Biglaw%20Job%20After%20Failing%20Bar%20Loses%20Disability%20Bias%20Suit%20Against%20Bar%20Examiners)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/harvard-law-grad-fired-from-biglaw-job-after-failing-bar-loses-disability-bias-suit-against-bar-examiners/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/07/harvard-law-grad-fired-from-biglaw-job-after-failing-bar-loses-disability-bias-suit-against-bar-examiners/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A Harvard Law graduate who failed the New York bar exam twice, lost her Biglaw job because of it, and filed a disability bias suit against the state’s Board of Law Examiners has now had that suit tossed out — and you might be able to guess why if you’re deep into studying for the bar exam right now.

First, we’ll provide some background. If you recall, back in 2016, the plaintiff in this case, now identified as T.W., sued the New York BOLE, alleging that she’d been denied testing accommodations on the bar exam that she’d received while in law school. It was because of this denial, she claimed, that she failed the bar exam twice in a row, which led to her losing her job at Ropes & Gray. “Once you are in a big, white-shoe law firm and you’re forced to leave, you are out of sync,” her lawyer [said at the time](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/biglaw-associate-fails-bar-gets-fired-sues-bar-examiners-for-causing-job-loss/). “The likelihood of getting another job at a big firm is slim to none. This has really derailed her career.” T.W. passed the exam on her third try, but a career in Biglaw had already passed her by.

So, why was this lawyer’s bar exam suit banished from court? According to Judge Raymond J. Dearie of the Eastern District of New York, the BOLE is like an arm of the state, and that means it’s entitled to sovereign immunity against ADA claims like the plaintiff in this case had levied.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
On top of Dearie booting T.W.’s last remaining cause of action — the Second Circuit kicked another one of her claims in 2021 — he went ahead and denied her the injunctive relief she sought to stop the BOLE from reporting her past exam results. An expungement, he noted, would simply not undo what had already been done. The [ABA Journal](https://www.abajournal.com/news/article/harvard-law-grad-loses-suit-claiming-lack-of-bar-exam-accommodations-nixed-her-biglaw-career) has the money quote from the judge:

“T.W. submits that she faces continuing injury because the record of her bar examination failures has hindered her job search and career prospects,” Dearie wrote. “But T.W. never alleges that a prospective employer has inquired about her bar examination record, much less made a hiring decision based on that record. Instead, she alleges that law firms have learned ‘that she did not have the opportunity to gain the experience they seek from a 2013 graduate due to the disruptions caused by her bar examination failure.’ … The court cannot rewrite history; expungement will neither alter T.W.’s level of experience nor undo the fact that she did not successfully pass the bar until 2015. Moreover, the injunctive relief T.W. requests would suppress a record that, according to the board, it is prohibited from disclosing to employers.”

T.W. may have spent the last few years of her life litigating against the New York BOLE and ended up with a loss, but it wasn’t exactly all for naught. At least future bar exam candidates in the state will know just how difficult it is to sue the bar examiners. That’s not what she was hoping for, but it’s something.

[Harvard Law grad loses suit claiming lack of bar exam accommodations nixed her BigLaw career](https://www.abajournal.com/news/article/harvard-law-grad-loses-suit-claiming-lack-of-bar-exam-accommodations-nixed-her-biglaw-career) [ABA Journal]

# How To Quit Biglaw In Style
## Life after Biglaw!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 11, 2021 at 2:43 PMAugust 13, 2021 at 11:07 AM
22
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/how-to-quit-biglaw-in-style/&text=How%20To%20Quit%20Biglaw%20In%20Style)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/how-to-quit-biglaw-in-style/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/how-to-quit-biglaw-in-style/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The dream of Biglaw isn’t the panacea you imagine it to be. Sure, the money’s good — and only getting better — but the hours, stress, and culture often leave a lot to be desired. Plus, there’s the added hassle of heading back to the physical office after a year+ proved Biglaw functions just fine in a virtual environment. It’s almost enough to make you want to quit…

Well, that’s exactly what one Biglaw associate did.

On the very same day she went back into the office for the first time since March 2020, Kim Daily — now a [former Eversheds associate](https://www.linkedin.com/in/kim-daily/) — handed in her resignation.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  

[
View this post on Instagram
](https://www.instagram.com/p/CRARGSqF7Dd/?utm_source=ig_embed&utm_campaign=loading)
[A post shared by Kim Daily (@iamkimdaily)](https://www.instagram.com/p/CRARGSqF7Dd/?utm_source=ig_embed&utm_campaign=loading)

So what’s next for this recovering Biglaw associate? She’s launched a brand [For the Qulture](http://www.forthequlture.com) and she’s dropping a tune that references her legal career, the MCU, and Lizzo.

The key line you’ll really feel?

$300k on the shelf, I quit my job for my health, but tell me is it really gamblin’ when you bettin’ on yourself?

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. # Top-Ranked Florida Biglaw Firm Issues Vaccine Mandate
## The state may be against COVID safety measures, but the firm is not.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 13, 2021 at 1:43 PMSeptember 28, 2021 at 9:56 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/top-ranked-florida-biglaw-firm-issues-vaccine-mandate/&text=Top-Ranked%20Florida%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Issues%20Vaccine%20Mandate)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/top-ranked-florida-biglaw-firm-issues-vaccine-mandate/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/top-ranked-florida-biglaw-firm-issues-vaccine-mandate/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Law firms continue to reverse course and change their plans when it comes to the reopening of their offices across thanks to the emergence of the COVID-19’s Delta variant. Vaccination mandates now seem to be the way of the future, and one by one, law firms are joining in to protect their employees and their local legal communities.

For reference, the following firms are requiring all employees to be vaccinated before they return to the office: [Akin Gump](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/more-biglaw-firms-will-require-employees-to-be-vaccinated-some-push-back-reopening-dates/?rf=1), [Arent Fox](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/more-biglaw-firms-mandate-vaccines-for-lawyers-and-staff/), [Ballard Spahr](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-heavy-hitters-add-vaccine-mandates-to-their-reopening-policies/), [Boies Schiller Flexner](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-heavy-hitters-add-vaccine-mandates-to-their-reopening-policies/), [Carlton Fields](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/skadden-mandates-vaccines-for-all-sidley-remains-mum-on-vaccination-but-pushes-back-reopening-date/), [Cleary Gottlieb](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-heavy-hitters-add-vaccine-mandates-to-their-reopening-policies/), [Clifford Chance](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/elite-firm-will-require-vaccination-but-other-reopening-policies-are-very-flexible/), [Cooley](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/top-20-biglaw-firm-wont-make-lawyers-return-to-office-in-2021-but-vaccines-will-be-required/), [Cozen O’Connor](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-firms-continue-to-roll-out-vaccine-mandates-delay-reopenings/), [Crowell & Moring](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/more-biglaw-firms-will-require-employees-to-be-vaccinated-some-push-back-reopening-dates/?rf=1), [Davis & Tremaine](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/the-first-biglaw-firm-to-announce-a-covid-19-vaccination-plan/), [Debevoise & Plimpton](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-firms-continue-to-roll-out-vaccine-mandates-delay-reopenings/), [Dickinson Wright](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/more-biglaw-and-boutique-firms-add-vaccination-requirements-for-employees-to-return-to-office/), [Faegre Drinker Biddle & Reath](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-firms-continue-to-roll-out-vaccine-mandates-delay-reopenings/), [Fenwick & Frank](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/more-biglaw-firms-mandate-vaccines-for-lawyers-and-staff/), [Goodwin](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/more-biglaw-firms-will-require-employees-to-be-vaccinated-some-push-back-reopening-dates/?rf=1), [Hanson Shaw](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-firms-continue-to-roll-out-vaccine-mandates-delay-reopenings/), [Sheppard Mulllin](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-heavy-hitters-add-vaccine-mandates-to-their-reopening-policies/), [Simpson Thacher](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/more-biglaw-firms-delay-openings-lay-down-strong-vaccination-policies/?rf=1), [Skadden](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/skadden-mandates-vaccines-for-all-sidley-remains-mum-on-vaccination-but-pushes-back-reopening-date/), [Stroock & Stroock & Lavan](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/biglaw-firms-continue-to-roll-out-vaccine-mandates-delay-reopenings/), [Weil Gotshal](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/05/weil-reopening/), [Wilson Sonsini](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/wsgr-delays-opening-delta/), and [Winston & Strawn](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/more-biglaw-firms-delay-openings-lay-down-strong-vaccination-policies/?rf=1).

The latest firm to issue a vaccine requirement is Greenberg Traurig, the first Florida-based Biglaw firm to announce such a measure. With Florida continuing to set COVID-19 case records and state government staunchly against mask mandates and other rational restrictions and safety measures, it’s no wonder that GT announced this new policy.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
According to the Daily Business Review, the firm has mandated COVID-19 vaccines for all employees across each and every one of its U.S. offices.

A firm spokesperson said individual office leaders were asked to consider mandating vaccines after the Delta variant caused a spike in case numbers and hospitalizations. The firm is nearly 90% vaccinated, the spokesperson said.

Holland & Knight, another Florida-based firm, is reportedly considering a vaccine requirement for employees but has not yet come to a final decison on the matter.

Will your firm be changing its plans when it comes to vaccination for attorneys and staff thanks to the Delta variant? Please let us know.

As soon as you find out about the reopening plan at your firm, please [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Office%20Reopening) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Office Reopening”) or text us at (646) 820-8477. We always keep our sources on stories anonymous. There’s no need to send a memo (if one exists) using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. If a memo has been circulated, please be sure to include it as proof; we like to post complete memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. Thanks.

# New White & Case Leader Reduced To Nameless 'Female Litigator' In Media Coverage
## This almost certainly wasn't intentional... which is the problem.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 28, 2023 at 1:13 PMJune 28, 2023 at 12:34 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/new-white-case-leader-reduced-to-nameless-female-litigator-in-media-coverage/&text=New%20White%20&%20Case%20Leader%20Reduced%20To%20Nameless%20‘Female%20Litigator’%20In%20Media%20Coverage)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/new-white-case-leader-reduced-to-nameless-female-litigator-in-media-coverage/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/new-white-case-leader-reduced-to-nameless-female-litigator-in-media-coverage/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Yesterday, [White & Case announced](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/change-in-leadership-at-white-case/) that Hugh Verrier would step down as the firm’s chair in September and Heather McDevitt would take over the firm’s top job. It’s exciting news in Biglaw when one of the top 10 firms by any metric embarks on a leadership change. All the legal press covered it.

One outlet’s coverage… left a little something to be desired.



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The replies tell the story of what happened next. Elon Musk won’t let the public see the number of replies anymore because he was tired of getting ratioed to death, but trust that they’ve accumulated for hours at this point. Here’s a slice of only the most recent…



The word is technically “litigatrix” per Black’s Law Dictionary ([via Above the Law itself](https://twitter.com/BryanAGarner/status/427931465989357569?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E427931465989357569%7Ctwgr%5E5d416f2b833dc70ba0c94c671a6004059a6cc9d4%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fjoshblackman.com%2Fblog%2F2014%2F01%2F27%2Fdavid-lat-has-coined-three-words-in-blacks-law-dictionary-and-i-got-a-slang-tweet-from-garner%2F)) — though I’ve never liked it when “litigator” is right there — but we’re pretty sure the commenter means something along the lines of “bias” or “sexism” in this instance.

Now, I suspect what happened here is that somewhere along the line, this conversation happened:

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Social media author: We’ll put “White & Case elects new leader”
Supervisor: Hmm. That’s a little bland. Is there anything interesting about this new leader?
Social media author: Well, Heather McDevitt is a female litigator… that might be a first for the firm?
Supervisor: Yeah… but if we tell them who is taking over in the Tweet, they might not click.
Social media author: Right, right. We could just say Hugh Verrier is stepping down.
Supervisor: That’s better, but then we lose the “female litigator” hook. Tell you what — say Verrier is stepping down and point out that his successor is a female litigator and then people will click to find out who she is.
Social media author: Brilliant, boss!
Supervisor: I know.

Had this headline just said “female litigator” and not mentioned Verrier, it would be a little weird — are people really not going to click if they see her name in the Tweet? — but I think most folks would write it off as an effort to preserve a little mystery for the readers. It’s the contrast that made this problematic because it grants a name to one party and not the other… while simultaneously reducing the latter to a demographic.

And this might be a bit of a trend. Compare:

Baker Botts LLP has elected litigation department co-chair Danny David as the firm's 16th managing partner. [https://t.co/K3Rql2cNtL](https://t.co/K3Rql2cNtL)

— Law360 (@Law360) [June 16, 2023](https://twitter.com/Law360/status/1669711298458689537?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

And contrast:

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
WilmerHale said that a longtime white collar litigator and strategic adviser will become its next managing partner effective Jan. 1. [https://t.co/v4WVP0pXSX](https://t.co/v4WVP0pXSX) [pic.twitter.com/7jE782NRAU](https://t.co/7jE782NRAU)

— Law360 (@Law360) [June 15, 2023](https://twitter.com/Law360/status/1669350671630614529?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

It’s not even limited to enticing readers to click to figure out about the “new” leader:

[](https://twitter.com/Law360/status/1631061785267650561?s=20)

To be clear, I doubt Law360 harbored any ill-intent here. There is a fine line to walk when it comes to coaxing readers to click on a story, and highlighting that the story features a successful lawyer from outside the white male box can draw an audience. Deftly phrased, zeroing in on “Woman Global Leader” or “Female Litigator” can celebrate achievement in a profession that often flops on diversity.

But… there’s not really any reason not to also name these lawyers and there’s certainly no reason to give that benefit to the white dudes’ names and not anyone else.

To be fair, Law360 generally makes it a habit to not name the incoming leader in these headlines (the Baker Botts story, while recent, is an outlier). And that’s fine if it’s the consistent practice.

This sort of thing happens when scrambling to produce content fast for a voracious audience. Above the Law has certainly had unintentional issues like this too. And they can get complex. Recently I used a generic stock image of a white person in a story and someone pointed out that the subject of the story was non-white. But the story was negative and dealt with ethical violations… should the generic image reflect the subject’s race even though race had nothing to do with the infraction and using the image could inject racist baggage on its own? It can be tough.

That said, this is not so tough.

The problem isn’t really that it happens in the first place — though that’s not good! — it’s how you approach it once it’s brought to your attention and avoid it going forward.

I think we’ve got sufficient notice now.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joepatrice@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news. Joe also serves as a [Managing Director at RPN Executive Search](https://www.rpnexecsearch.com/josephpatrice).

# Biglaw Firm Matches The Cravath Scale, With No Special Bonuses In Sight
## Associates really aren't pleased by this.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 13, 2022 at 12:43 PMJanuary 19, 2022 at 9:36 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/crowell-bonus-2021/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Matches%20The%20Cravath%20Scale,%20With%20No%20Special%20Bonuses%20In%20Sight)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/crowell-bonus-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/crowell-bonus-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s mid-January, and here on the East Coast, it is C-O-L-D, cold. Coincidentally, Biglaw is still matching the weather with cold, hard cash as bonus season continues and the largest law firms in America reward associates and counsel for all their hard work.

Our latest featured bonus comes from Crowell & Moring, which brought in $514,391,000 in gross revenue in 2020, putting it in 77th place on the Am Law 100. When we last checked in with the firm, it had decided to implement a [two-tier compensation system](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/crowell-raises/) based on billable hours, effective September 1, 2021. Those who billed 2000 or more hours would be compensated on the Davis Polk scale, with cash ranging from $205,000 to $365,000, while those who billed 1900 hours would receive somewhat reduced compensation, ranging from $185,00 to $340,000.

As it turns out, Crowell announced bonuses via email quite some time ago, before [Davis Polk’s scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/davis-polk-bonuses-21) yet again became the prevailing market rate after the firm announced that it would be adding special bonuses on top of the already generous [Cravath year-end bonus scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/first-mover-on-bonus/). Perhaps associates were waiting for the firm to change its tune and raise up bonuses to the market standard before reaching out to us but unfortunately, those revisions never came.

One frustrated source — who claims that Crowell & Moring was also undermarket on previous special bonuses — tells us that with respect to year-end bonuses, the firm “[d]id not adjust to the new scale” and there has been “no word at all on adjustments.” Eek. Hopefully associates will be able to hold on for more money but if not… the lateral market is certainly hot, hot, hot enough to put a little pep in their step and bring their bank accounts back to life.

UPDATE: Another source tells us that while Crowell matched the Cravath scale, it was the old Cravath scale that went up to $100K for senior associates, not the current scale that goes up to $115K for senior associates. Ooof!

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Stat Of The Week: Growing Discontent
## Rising burnout takes its toll. 
By [Jeremy Barker](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jbarker/)  
onJuly 9, 2021 at 1:43 PMJuly 9, 2021 at 1:51 PM
34
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/stat-of-the-week-growing-discontent/&text=Stat%20Of%20The%20Week:%20Growing%20Discontent)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/stat-of-the-week-growing-discontent/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/stat-of-the-week-growing-discontent/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Lawyers soured on their work early this year, with increasing burnout likely weighing on their short-term job satisfaction, according to a new report. 

Bloomberg Law’s second [Attorney Workload & Hours Survey](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/analysis-survey-finds-lawyer-burnout-rising-well-being-falling) reveals a disparity between lawyers’ overall job satisfaction and how they felt about the first quarter of 2021.

For overall job satisfaction, the survey has some good news: Almost 60% of respondents rated it at least 7 out of 10, mirroring previous results. 

But when asked about job satisfaction in Q1, that number plummets to 44%. 

Unsurprisingly, this drop coincides with a rise in burnout — respondents said they experienced burnout 50% of the time in the Q1 survey, compared with 40% of the time in a prior survey looking at 2020.  

As Bloomberg notes: 

“This increase in burnout may be negatively impacting how satisfied attorneys are presently, but if conditions leading to increased burnout are directly related to the pandemic, respondents’ overall job satisfaction may not wane as they realize (or hope) that their work/life balance will return to pre-pandemic levels sooner rather than later.”

[ANALYSIS: Survey Finds Lawyer Burnout Rising, Well-Being Falling](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/analysis-survey-finds-lawyer-burnout-rising-well-being-falling) [Bloomberg Law]

Jeremy Barker is the director of content marketing for Breaking Media. Feel free to [email him](mailto:jbarker@breakingmedia.com) with questions or comments and to [connect on LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jeremy-barker-5316a230/).

# How Law Departments Can Make Innovation Stick
## Closing the gap between *buying* technology and *using* technology.
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onOctober 25, 2022 at 12:12 PMOctober 25, 2022 at 11:06 AM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/how-law-departments-can-make-innovation-stick/&text=How%20Law%20Departments%20Can%20Make%20Innovation%20Stick)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/how-law-departments-can-make-innovation-stick/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/how-law-departments-can-make-innovation-stick/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Tech advocates on in-house teams face unique challenges.

How can they ensure the changes they push for are not only implemented, but also are effective in improving workflows? 

How can they avoid the dreaded long-term fallout from a failed implementation? How can they ensure that buying technology equates to using technology — and doing so effectively? 

In “How Today’s Challenges Are Forging Tomorrow’s Top GCs,” legal tech experts Michele Alwin of Wolters Kluwer and Lucy Bassli of InnoLaw Group explored these questions with the legal tech journalist Bob Ambrogi.

Here, we share a few of their insights on making innovation stick. 

[(View the full webinar here.)](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/how-todays-challenges-are-forging-tomorrows-top-gcs/)

Focus on Education

While lawyers handle highly sophisticated work, they are often inexperienced when it comes to technology. As a result, the panelists noted, vendors have an obligation to provide a thorough educational journey to their clients.

“Just like I hope that when my plumber comes over, they won’t just give me the invoice and say, ‘Sure, I can fix that,’” Bassli says. “Give me some options. Tell me why. Tell me what happened! What am I going to do to prevent it next time?”

Bassli also notes that failed implementations can leave “deep scars” for organizations, harming the credibility of a project’s advocates and creating resistance to future change. 

In her work with Wolters Kluwer’s Legisway, Alwin hears some “bad back stories” from customers about past experiences with technology. This can in turn create challenges in helping customers understand how Legisway is different from these prior experiences, she says. 

“I think one thing that sometimes gets a little bit lost is: We’re talking about legal tech here, and that’s important, but to the buyer it’s a lot less about legal tech than it is about solving a problem, about improving their workflow.” 

Once new tech has been successfully implemented and the necessary support infrastructure is in place, it’s crucial to produce tangible results. 

“I want to see real progress. I want to see a lawyer go: ‘Thank God I don’t have to review another NDA,’” says Bassli. “That’s progress … I want to see those outcomes, those values, those benefits.”

Join Wolters Kluwer at the ACC Meeting

Wolters Kluwer is located at booth #334, and attendees are invited to join the team as they demo Legisway. 

Fill out the form below to view this webinar.

 

####Topics
[ACC Annual Meeting](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/acc-annual-meeting/), [Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Webinars](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/webinars/), [Wolters Kluwer](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/wolters-kluwer/)

# Non-Sequiturs: 08.16.16
## * Former NYPD police office Peter Liang didn't have to serve jail time over the killing of Akai Gurley, but he (and the city of New York) will have to pay to settle the civil lawsuit. [[Huffington Post](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/new-york-police-settle-liang_us_57b312e7e4b0c75f49d821cc?section=&)] * The Supreme Court does no favors for victims of police brutality. [[Slate](http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2016/08/how_the_supreme_court_has_failed_victims_of_police_brutality_like_sylville.html)] * How will Jones Day rebrand itself if (when?) its client, Donald Trump, fails? [[Law and More](http://lawandmore.typepad.com/law_and_more/2016/08/its-now-the-after-trump-the-great-rebranding.html)] * Republican lawmakers are pushing for a perjury case to be brought against Hillary Clinton. [[Law Newz](http://lawnewz.com/high-profile/lawmakers-outline-potential-perjury-case-against-clinton-in-letter-to-u-s-attorney/)] * Donald Trump unveiled a new immigration plan, but not everyone thinks it passes the legality bar. [[Salon](http://www.salon.com/2016/08/16/extreme-vetting-will-paul-ryan-and-mitch-mcconnell-go-along-with-trumps-crazy-immigration-plan/)] * Wherein Kelly Ayotte tries to delicately dance around the issue of endorsing Donald Trump while still being a good Republican soldier. [[Lawyers, Guns and Money](http://www.lawyersgunsmoneyblog.com/2016/08/a-vote-is-an-endorsement)]
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)

# Blum Group Threatens To Sue More Biglaw Firms Over Their Diversity Fellowships
## One of them has already scrapped its program in response.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 13, 2023 at 3:15 PMOctober 13, 2023 at 12:54 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/blum-group-threatens-to-sue-more-biglaw-firms-over-their-diversity-fellowships/&text=Blum%20Group%20Threatens%20To%20Sue%20More%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Over%20Their%20Diversity%20Fellowships)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/blum-group-threatens-to-sue-more-biglaw-firms-over-their-diversity-fellowships/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/blum-group-threatens-to-sue-more-biglaw-firms-over-their-diversity-fellowships/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

To avoid litigation, the Alliance hopes these law firms will immediately modify their programs to bring them into compliance with our nation’s civil rights laws. No student should be treated differently because of their race or ethnicity.

— Edward Blum, leader of the American Alliance for Equal Rights, in comments given to [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/blum-threatens-more-law-firms-over-diversity-hiring-programs) over the organization’s threats against diversity fellowship programs at Winston & Strawn, Hunton Andrews & Kurth, and Adams and Reese. In response to the threat of litigation, Adams and Reese decided to do away with its program, saying it will not be accepting applications for its “1L Minority Fellowship.” The Alliance has already [filed suit](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/two-biglaw-firms-sued-over-diversity-initiatives/) against Morrison Foerster and Perkins Coie, which [both](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/biglaw-caves-morrison-foerster-changes-diversity-fellowship-criteria-following-lawsuit/) [revised](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/perkins-coie-diversity-fellowship/) their DEI fellowships to remove race as a factor, leading to the lawsuits being dropped.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Americans Rank Law Firms Dead Last In Commitment To Diversity
## According to a new survey looking at 11 major industries, law firms are perceived to have the lowest commitment to diversity when it comes to hiring and retention.
By [Renwei Chung](https://abovethelaw.com/author/renweichung/)  
onApril 8, 2016 at 1:32 PMFebruary 9, 2023 at 1:35 AM
45
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/americans-rank-law-firms-dead-last-in-commitment-to-diversity/&text=Americans%20Rank%20Law%20Firms%20Dead%20Last%20In%20Commitment%20To%20Diversity)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/americans-rank-law-firms-dead-last-in-commitment-to-diversity/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/americans-rank-law-firms-dead-last-in-commitment-to-diversity/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
“First I took the time out, then I put the time in / Money ain’t everything, it’s more about the timing.” – [Fabolous](http://genius.com/20528)

This week, research experts [McGinn and Company](http://mcginnandcompany.com/Default.aspx) and [Repass Research](http://repassinc.com/) published a [survey](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-d54rTHlQeYdVpMdWIwWERYaWc/view?usp=sharing) revealing that — among 11 major industries — law firms are perceived to have the lowest commitment to diversity when it comes to [hiring](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/05/3-things-law-firms-can-do-right-now-to-increase-diversity-in-the-legal-profession/) and [retention](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/high-minority-attrition-rates-continue-to-plague-large-law-firms/).

We already know that representation of minorities in the law [has barely budged](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/minorities-in-the-legal-profession-have-increased-by-less-than-one-percent-since-2000/) since 2000, and the [2020 data](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/without-significant-changes-diversity-in-the-legal-profession-will-remain-on-life-support/) about our profession probably won’t be much different. “This should be a wake-up call for the legal profession. The public simply doesn’t believe that law firms care much about diversity,” said Dan McGinn of McGinn and Company. “Expectations are rising in this arena and the legal profession needs to move from laggard to [leader](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/01/tech-industry-leaders-are-beginning-to-accept-the-diversity-challenge-u-s-law-partners-should-do-the-same/?rf=1).”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
“One irony of this nation’s continuing struggle for diversity and gender equity in employment is that the profession leading the struggle has failed to set an example in its own workplaces,” [according](http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2674201) to [Deborah L. Rhode](https://www.law.stanford.edu/profile/deborah-l-rhode), director of the Program in Law and Social Entrepreneurship at Stanford University. “In principle, the bar is deeply committed to equal opportunity and social justice. In practice, it lags behind other occupations in leveling the playing field.”

In the McGinn-Repass national diversity survey, 1,156 adult respondents rated eleven different industries — based on what they read or heard, or their own experience — on each industry’s respective efforts to attract and retain a diverse workforce. Based on these ratings, the industries were ranked by largest percent above average to lowest percent below average for perceived commitment to diversity. The final results were weighted based on gender, age, race and household income to be representative of the U.S. population.

Law firms came in dead last with a net-minus 1 score. Even with [#OscarSoWhite](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/what-do-the-oscars-and-the-legal-profession-have-in-common/), the [media](http://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2015/07/minorities-in-journalism/399461/) and [entertainment](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/09/92-of-biglaw-partners-are-white-is-this-problematic/) industries ranked significantly higher for perceived commitment to diversity than the [legal profession](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/for-most-law-students-will-the-value-of-a-law-degree-exceed-its-cost/). Noticeably absent from this list is the [technology industry](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/the-curious-case-of-ellen-pao-one-year-later/). Do you believe the legal profession has a better or worse public perception of commitment to diversity than the technology sector?

Without further ado, here are the rankings (with percentage from average indicated parenthetically):

###Sponsored

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
- Higher Education (+43%)
- Healthcare (+35%)
- Restaurants (+34%)
- Hotels (+33%)
- Government (+29%)
- Manufacturing (+29%)
- Media (+24%)
- Entertainment (+23%)
- Finance (+9%)
- Accounting (+5%)
- Law Firms (-1%)
On Wednesday, I had the opportunity to catch up with research expert Dan McGinn to discuss this survey. Here is an excerpt from our conversation:

Renwei Chung (RC): According to your survey, Americans see the legal profession as the least committed industry to diversity in the nation. How would you explain these results?

Dan McGinn (DM): The public simply doesn’t believe that law firms care much about diversity. Our experience is that people are pretty savvy. They see government, higher education, and the entertainment and hospitality industry as more receptive to hiring a diverse workforce.

RC: What surprised you the most about the respondents’ answers to your survey?

DM: There were two surprising results. On a positive note, more than 7 out of 10 people believe that workplaces with a diverse employee base will be more successful. On a troubling note, the public believes that recent protests such as the Black Lives Matter campaign and the protest around the Oscars will make it harder to achieve an improvement in race relations.

RC: From your perspective, what can law firms do to change the public’s perception of their inclusiveness and also affect real change in their cultures and environments?

DM: The first thing law firms should do is recognize that diversity is a priority issue with the public. Pressure on professional firms of all types to increase their commitment to diversity will rise rapidly in the years ahead.

RC: Why do you believe diversity and inclusion is important to an industry?

DM: I won’t make the social, moral argument. I think that is self-evident. And I won’t make the economic argument either. My view of the importance of diversity is more fundamental. The 21st Century is about the race for brainpower. It’s true for every organization, community and country. And brainpower isn’t determined by race, gender, sexual preference, ethnicity, or religious views. There is only strategy for winning the brain race — hire the smartest people. Period.

At the end of our conversation, McGinn reminded me that this survey is purely about perception. There is a public awareness and concern about how law firms are dealing with diversity and inclusion, according to McGinn. He further stated that the margin of error and time to deal with these issues appropriately is whittling down.

This public perception poll should make clear to us in the legal profession that diversity and inclusion are no longer just internal issues that we on the inside are struggling to address. There is a public perception that the [legal universe isn’t inclusive](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/01/for-most-law-students-will-the-value-of-a-law-degree-exceed-its-cost/). In this case, is the public’s perception our [reality](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/09/92-of-biglaw-partners-are-white-is-this-problematic/)?

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
I happen to believe there are a [number of law firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/07/the-best-law-firms-for-diversity-2016/) that are beginning to proactively address these issues, but as an industry we could do more. Law firms must [substantively do more](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/08/4-thoughts-about-closing-the-diversity-gap-in-the-legal-profession/) and do a [better job](https://hbr.org/2015/10/firms-are-wasting-millions-recruiting-on-only-a-few-campuses?utm_source=Socialflow&utm_medium=Tweet&utm_campaign=Socialflow) of telling their story if they wish to [effectively address](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/08/5-takeaways-from-mckinseys-diversity-matters-report-for-the-legal-profession/) the [diversity crisis](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/05/3-things-law-firms-can-do-right-now-to-increase-diversity-in-the-legal-profession/) in our industry.

The time is more than ripe for us to [change the narrative](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/01/can-millennials-disrupt-the-biglaw-status-quo-bias-toward-diversity/).

[Renwei Chung](https://www.linkedin.com/in/taichung/) is the DEI Columnist at [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/renweichung/). He currently serves as a Board Advisor for [The Diversity Movement (TDM)](https://thediversitymovement.com/dei-navigator/), whose integrated approach enables law firms to build and strengthen culture by tying real-world business outcomes to DEI initiatives via a scalable subscription-based employee experience platform. And he is excited to host TDM’s and Footnote 4’s new podcast Charge the Wave — focused on entrepreneurs, executives, and icons who are assiduously building companies, cultures, and communities.

# Two Firms Opened Up The Bonus Coffers Right Before The Holiday
## The holidays were bright for associates at these firms.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 27, 2021 at 7:05 PMDecember 27, 2021 at 7:56 PM
17
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/two-firms-opened-up-the-bonus-coffers-right-before-the-holiday/&text=Two%20Firms%20Opened%20Up%20The%20Bonus%20Coffers%20Right%20Before%20The%20Holiday)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/two-firms-opened-up-the-bonus-coffers-right-before-the-holiday/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/two-firms-opened-up-the-bonus-coffers-right-before-the-holiday/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
After most of us took a break to begin the holiday festivities, we got news of a few more bonuses out there. And it turns out there’s some connective tissue among the firms we heard from. We’ve already talked about [AZA](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/aza-bonus-2021/) — the Texas-based boutique issuing its bonuses. But we’ve also heard from Haynes and Boone and Locke Lord about their matches.

Both firms handle bonuses individually, but it sounds like both staked their claim to play with the rest of Biglaw:

First, Haynes and Boone, which opts for a black-box structure:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Blackbox bonus structure, but seems like it was full match across the board. Full market bonus and special bonus. No bonus for billing above the 2000 hour threshold, which many find disappointing. Generally, associates seem happy that HB continues to match the standard market and special bonus amounts – but frustrating that things aren’t always clear in this “black box” model.

We couldn’t agree more when it comes to transparency.

Locke Lord may send out a memo eventually, but for now they’re handling via phone. The firm offered even more cash, catching up on Fall bonuses:

Some associates received the call today about bonuses and they are ecstatic to say the least. Included in the bonuses are a fall bonus, Covid bonus, and our regular bonuses. We did not know a fall bonus was coming. Many mid levels associates in the mid six figures. I got 30% more money than I was expecting if that gives you an idea. I’m very, very happy. Locke lord has always been a great place to work but this is above and beyond.

###Sponsored

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
This is all great news for associates across the country at these Lone Star-based firms.

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# This Biglaw Firm Is Mastering Twitter
## Or X or whatever we're calling it now.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 30, 2023 at 7:03 PMNovember 30, 2023 at 5:13 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/this-biglaw-firm-is-mastering-twitter/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Is%20Mastering%20Twitter)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/this-biglaw-firm-is-mastering-twitter/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/this-biglaw-firm-is-mastering-twitter/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. Note: Welcome to our daily feature [Trivia Question of the Day!](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/)

According to Good2bSocial’s 2023 Social Law Firm Index, which Am Law 200 firm performs the best on Twitter (X)?

Hint: According to the firm’s Senior Marketing and Communications Manager, “We have launched X pages for select practice groups to give them the opportunity to enhance their reputations and achieve stronger client relationships by sharing targeted content. This has allowed us to develop best practices for our other platforms and to engage with followers that we do not see elsewhere. Our strategy changed after we experienced a surge in followers last year that led us to focus more on our firm page instead of practice group offshoots.”

# Another Biglaw Firm Admits It Overreacted To COVID-19, Will Partially Walk Back Salary Cuts
## Not a surprise that law firms were overly cautious in the face of uncertainty.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 26, 2020 at 2:14 PMAugust 26, 2020 at 1:50 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/another-biglaw-firm-admits-it-overreacted-to-covid-19-will-partially-walk-back-salary-cuts/&text=Another%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Admits%20It%20Overreacted%20To%20COVID-19,%20Will%20Partially%20Walk%20Back%20Salary%20Cuts)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/another-biglaw-firm-admits-it-overreacted-to-covid-19-will-partially-walk-back-salary-cuts/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/another-biglaw-firm-admits-it-overreacted-to-covid-19-will-partially-walk-back-salary-cuts/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The trend of Biglaw firms pulling back from the height of their COVID-19 economic concerns continues. More and more, we’re seeing firms that decided to cut salaries when faced with the economic uncertainty of the pandemic change course, and re-institute at lease some of the cuts.

[Back in April](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/biglaw-firm-announces-up-to-20-percent-pay-cuts-to-avoid-layoffs/), Loeb & Loeb announced some salary cuts, as a way to avoid layoffs. Partners took the hardest hit, with draws slashed by 20 percent. Income partners, senior counsel, of counsel, associates, and senior staff had their salary cut by 15 percent and paralegals and other staff saw 10 percent cuts. But that’s changing.

Yesterday, firm chair Kenneth Florin announced via memo that “the impact of this pandemic on our business has not been as damaging as we had feared.” But that the firm is “very much aware that this pandemic is far from over and its overall impact not yet clear.” So, as a result, as [reported by](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/loeb-loeb-latest-law-firm-to-roll-back-pandemic-salary-cuts) Bloomberg Law, Loeb & Loeb will see a partial reversal of their salary cuts.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Effective September 1st, the cuts will be reduced by 60 percent for income partners, senior counsel, of counsel, associates, paralegals and staff. The reductions to the monthly capital partner draws will remain in place. Florin also said the firm plans to award their annual year-end bonuses.

Let’s hope it’s only a matter of time before full salaries are restored.

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries or restoring previous cuts, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the layoff alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

# Professional Paralegals Deserve More Respect
## Professional paralegals can be extremely valuable to law firms, and more shops should respect and invest in professional paralegals.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onSeptember 30, 2020 at 4:34 PMSeptember 30, 2020 at 2:42 PM
41
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/professional-paralegals-deserve-more-respect/&text=Professional%20Paralegals%20Deserve%20More%20Respect)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/professional-paralegals-deserve-more-respect/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/professional-paralegals-deserve-more-respect/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Law firms typically take a few different approaches to how they treat paralegals. Some shops view paralegals as temporary, somewhat transitional employees, who will likely depart the firm after a certain period of time. Indeed, some prospective law students often take paralegals jobs to get legal experience before heading to law school, and others may wish to work as a paralegal for a year or two to see if they want to become attorneys. Moreover, there is an extremely inaccurate and unfair perception among some in the legal community that many paralegals are simply individuals who did not have the skill, time, or patience to become lawyers (which I always thought was weird, since many attorneys regret their own career choices!). However, some firms view paralegals as integral, long-term members of their team and invest time and resources to develop their paralegal staff. For a variety of reasons, professional paralegals can be extremely valuable to law firms, and more shops should respect and invest in professional paralegals.

Legal Knowledge

As many attorneys know from first-hand experience, professional paralegals often learn valuable information about the practice of law. This can be important to shops, especially if there is a high rate of attorney turnover at a firm. For instance, after leaving Biglaw, I landed at a “street law” shop at which I had to appear in court several times a week and understand the hands-on mechanics of litigation. As an associate in Biglaw, I basically just wrote memos and conducted legal research, and I did not learn any practical know-how about litigating cases.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Within my first week of working at this “street law” firm, I was given the simple task of drafting and filing a stipulation extending the time for us to oppose a summary judgment motion. I had absolutely no idea how to write such a document or how to file the stipulation with the court. However, the paralegal (and secretary) assigned to my team helped me draft the stipulation and told me what provisions needed to be included in this document. They then provided me with detailed instructions on when I needed to submit the document to the court, which courtroom I had to submit the document to (Room 130, of course, as my New York City colleagues would know!), and what I had to say to the clerk when I submitted the document. I relied on my paralegal (and secretary — I might have to do another article on how valuable legal secretaries can be!) heavily during my first few months at that “street law” firm before I learned the ropes of litigation, and that shop benefited greatly from the professional paralegals who were working there. Moreover, when I moved to a different firm that focused on a few mass torts matters, the paralegals provided invaluable advice on how procedures worked in those cases. Mass torts cases often develop their own rules and procedures, and professional paralegals can help attorneys stay on top of how issues are handled in those matters.

Client Relationships

Professional paralegals are also important because they can forge long-term and strong connections to in-house counterparts. If a paralegal leaves a firm after a year or two, it might be difficult for in-house professionals to forge connections with paralegals, which can influence a client’s decision to stay with a given firm. However, if paralegals stay at a firm for years, these connections are easier to make.

For instance, I once worked at a mass torts shop that handled a few large mass torts matters for several big clients. Even though the other associates and I rarely had contact with individuals who worked for our clients, the paralegals were in communication with in-house people all the time. Our paralegals would consistently send reports, notes, and other materials to in-house people and answer all kinds of questions. In addition, the paralegals were very familiar with the procedures that in-house professionals wanted us to use for billing and other administrative tasks. Since mass torts matters can take many years to be resolved, the paralegals at my firm were well-acquainted with some of the folks who worked for our clients. I am sure that this connection helped our firm retain these clients over the years because clients appreciate the relationships they had with professionals at our firm which would disappear if the clients went elsewhere.
